data.title: Hot Exit: properly restore dirty editors
data.body:
Feedback for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/b23229f65dd68c594915650e0e2aed722cdaa401

I think you will run quickly into an issue where dirty files will not get restored in the way it works now because a user can decide to start code with a specific file to open or folder and you would not run into the `restoreEditor()` case and not reopen dirty files. 

I agree though that we should try to restore as much of the previous session state as possible to keep the user happy. 

There are two cases:

1.) the user just opens Code without passing in arguments. In that case the restoreEditors() call will restore all files and you are adding the untitled ones to have the complete picture.

2.) the user opens code with a specific file in mind like so: `code.sh ~/Desktop/test-js/ ~/Desktop/test-js/package.json`. In this case we will not `restoreEditors()`. You will still need to massage the `filesToOpen` to include the backup files and you will also need to add the untitled files that contain dirty changes.

data.title: A few error messages in my ts file
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.6.1 - OS Version: 10.11.6 Steps to Reproduce: 1. `git clone https://github.com/bsliran/angular2-meteor-base.git demo` 2. Open `app.component.ts` The first error is: `[ts] Cannot find module './app.component.html'.` The second error is: `[ts] Experimental support for decorators is a feature that is subject to change in a future release. Set the 'experimentalDecorators' option to remove this warning.` After I insert to .vscode/settings.json: ``` { "typescript.tsdk": "/usr/local/lib/node_modules/typescript/lib" } ``` The problem exists. My tsconfig.json: ``` { "compilerOptions": { "target": "es5", "lib": [ "es6", "dom" ], "module": "commonjs", "moduleResolution": "node", "experimentalDecorators": true, "emitDecoratorMetadata": true, "sourceMap": true }, "exclude": [ "node_modules" ], "files": [ "typings.d.ts" ], "compileOnSave": false, "angularCompilerOptions": { "genDir": "aot", "skipMetadataEmit": true } } ``` I think the code itself has no problem because I can run the app without problem. But it shows the error message. What should I do? Thanks.

data.title: Regex can't support Zero-Length Assertions
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.6.1
- OS Version:win10 1607

Steps to Reproduce:
1. toggle search palette
2. input expression like`/(?<=\w)\w/`
3. it will show that "Invalid regular expression"

If it possible to add this property to vscode, or if I miss some settings to open this feature.

data.title: Diagnostic hovers adding indentation with \n
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win10 w/ anniversary update

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a diagnostic with the message property set to text that contains newlines (\n).  For example:
   diagnostic.message = "\nSeverity: Critical\nHere are details about the Error";
2. hover over whatever code is tied to the diagnostic to show the message.  Prior to 1.6 this would appear as:

[Source]
Severity: Critical
Here are details about the error

As one would expect.  However, in 1.6 and above both Severity and "Here are the details..." will also start with a heavy indentation, as if there are a number of tabs inserted

data.title: Watches pane - "Rename expression" -> "Edit expression"
data.body: 'Rename' doesn't feel right here. I was going to make the change but don't know whether the localize ID, action name, and everything else should change to be consistent.

data.title: Feature Request: Make package.json "scripts" click-to-run
data.body:
feature request!

fulfill the following workflow:
- open package.json
- adjacent to anything in `scripts: { ... }`, add a little icon that I can click to run it!
- additionally, alternatively, parse the `scripts: { ... }` and add them to the launch configuration menu automatically

frequently I find myself re-creating those scripts in my launch.json... but it seems like an easy win to just make them runable by default!

data.title: Feature Request: Drag and drop Watch variables
data.body:
I'm getting used to the debugger and it's been really helpful, but it can be difficult to manage at times. I thought giving users the ability to re-order watch items would be nice. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10404888/19580432/cc0385a4-96eb-11e6-98ba-edfe358b5dd0.png)

Sometimes I'm watching variables that have similar names but are from different files. It can get a little confusing when there's several watch variables from different locations. I'll put dummy variables between them as dividers to remind me which file they came from.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10404888/19580577/cd12d232-96ec-11e6-9d23-13e361719451.png)

Being able to do these sorts of things quickly would be awesome. Currently I have to delete and rebuild the entire watch list if I feel the need to re-order or add something in an ordered fashion.

data.title: Unable to next/previous via keybindings when diff editor is not focused
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:
1. bind `ctrl+down` and `ctrl+up` to `workbench.action.compareEditor.nextChange` and `workbench.action.compareEditor.previousChange` with `when` set to `textCompareEditorVisible`.
2. open the git panel with some changes to view.
3. _single_-click a file in the `CHANGES` list to select it and show its diff on the right.
4. try hitting `ctrl+down` and/or `ctrl+up` to navigate the changes _while the git panel still has focus_.

Navigating the file diff with `ctrl+down/up` used to work when single-clicking a file in the `CHANGES` list when this feature was first released. This broken sometime within the past several versions (I should've reported the regression sooner), and now you have to actually focus a file by double-clicking a `CHANGES` entry or manually clicking in one of the two displayed files on the right. This has become increasingly annoying enough that I finally remembered to make an issue about it :-)

Anyway, please restore the previous behavior when you have a chance, as the `when` context name suggests it should merely be `visible` rather than `focused`! The feature was really nice and streamlined before, but has become a bottleneck now for us keyboard navigators. With the `CHANGES` list in continual focus, it was really nice to be able to `up/down` in the list to select files, and then `ctrl+up/down` to scan through their changes.

Thanks in advance!

data.title: [typescript] VS Code won't use lib ES2015 type definitions
data.body:
I'm trying to use some ES2015 features (specifically `Object.assign`).

Since typescript 2, [there is built in type definitions for ES2015 using the `--lib` option](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/What's-new-in-TypeScript#including-built-in-type-declarations-with---lib) and similarly, there is a `lib` `compilerOptions` key in the `tsconfig.json` file.

I have the `lib` option changed to contain `es2015`. My project compiles fine with from `tsc` with no errors but VS Code yells at me for using `Object.assign` and other ES2015 features.

I see that VS Code actually contains the type definitions in `Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\extensions\typescript\server\typescript\lib\lib.es2015.d.ts`.

**Is there a way to get vs code to use those type definitions? Is this a bug and should this already happen?**

I already have webpack including the respective polyfills but I can't seem to get the type definitions working in vs code. Any ideas?

Thanks!
- VSCode Version:
  1.6.1
- OS Version:
  Windows 10
  Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use vs code to open a typescript project with es2015 types with an es5 target.
2. Observe that vs code yells at you
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10551026/19578450/af229184-96e9-11e6-947f-6ec9b04da7e5.png)

data.title: [less] Bad highlighting for first parentheses in id-mixins
onDidCloseTextEditor triggering on preview pane that is still open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OSX

Related to #13623 . From that I learned that preview panes (virtual documents) have a 3 minute timer that clean ups unused virtual files. However, it appears as though this is attempting to clean up documents that are not closed, but simply not currently visible.

[Open preview panes](http://imgur.com/MnaR597)

[onDidCloseTextEditor triggering for a preview pane I have open](http://imgur.com/ZYhPbfW)

This is a problem because this means we can not trust this onDidCloseTextDocument event in order to know when to clean up data, meaning we have to hold on to data forever. Is this expected behavior? Is there a `vscode.window.visibleTextEditors` but for all open files so we can check to see if a html pane has actually been closed?

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two html preview panes
2. Wait for the three minute clean up to trigger and on did close document will trigger for a document you already have open but not visible.

data.title: Implement Hot Exit
data.body:
- #14200 Hot Exit: Support hot exit on folder workspaces
- #12400 Original hot exit PR
- #14055 Hot Exit: avoid direct calls to fs.readdir()/fs.readdirSync() (aab05a86f5a959accce2fa388a36fb2cbc603f2b)
- #14060 Correctly clean up workspace backups when exiting (873d095ac3555c1853a1636bb052b7fbaee8ea49)
- #14100 & #14067 Have TextFileEditorModel handle restores (b23229f65dd68c594915650e0e2aed722cdaa401)
- #14068 Hot Exit: do not load backup files to restore sync on startup in the renderer
- #14065 Hot Exit: push renderer backup logic into new backup service
- #14066 Hot Exit: backupService.ts feedback
- Big refactor to throw as much as possible into the now several `Backup*Service`s and leverage events
- #14079 Remove public backup()
- #14074 Hot Exit: Careful when you veto the shutdown from failing backups
- #14181 Introduce on model dispose events to ITextFileEditorModelManager and IUntitledEditorService and track in BackupModelService
- #14180 Don't hash untitled resource names for their backup paths
- #14037 Merge backup path logic from node/fileService.ts into backupService.ts
- #14064 Hot Exit: backupService saves and loads a LOT - _Resources are no longer tracked at all in workspace.json and instead the actual backup path is checked_
- #14063 Hot Exit: deal with backup workspaces that do not exist anymore
- #14056 Hot Exit: backup workspace handling should all happen on main side
- #14330 Hot exit: Reloading the window should restore all files in the window
- #14132 Hot Exit: restoring file model issues
- #13305 Hot Exit: Support multiple folder restore (5bb2cb8470e2ef00de464beb042ec1866141311c, 57c6e72e5dacd8cfa72241a07039510d4f9bf6b5)
- #15134 Hot exit on Mac currently allows closing the final single window
- #15130 Cannot exit empty workspace windows on Windows when hot exit is enabled
- #15137 Close folder does not clear the backup workspace path

data.title: Creating a keymap extension - why is `key` necessary?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While building a keymap extension (that is an extension that adds contributions to `contributes.keybindings`) I ran into an issue where `"key"` was a required property. I opened https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14111 to address the lack of JSON validation. 

Another concern here is the necessity of `"key"`. Why is this necessary? 

Consider an approach as follow:

``` json
{
  "mac": "cmd+shift+l",
  "command": "editor.action.insertCursorAtEndOfEachLineSelected",
  "when": "editorTextFocus"
}
```

My intent here is to override the default keybinding for Mac only. I want to use the default keybinding for Windows and Linux. I do not want to have to specify a `"key"` attribute because I want to use VS Code's keybinding for Windows and Linux.

data.title: Needed validation in `contributes.keybindings` for extension manifest
data.body:
While building a keymap extension I ran into an issue. 

I created a keybinding contribution as seen below:

``` json
{
  "mac": "ctrl+shift+pageup",
  "win": "alt+shift+pageup",
  "linux": "alt+shift+pageup",
  "command": "cursorColumnSelectPageUp",
  "when": "editorTextFocus" 
}
```

What is wrong with the above? 

Once I debugged the extension I found the issue. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19569406/77f42bee-96aa-11e6-937b-9c9cc4eaf2bb.png)

Two things could be fixed here:

1 - The error message is too large and so I cannot see what is going on. I did figure out that I can see the same error in the debug console. It would be better if there was a way to see the complete message in the error box. (ping @bgashler1 @stevencl on this one)
2 - I would've expected to have caught this with the JSON validation of the file. We should introduce a squiggle line indicating that the keybinding object is missing a required `"key"` property. 
3 - The error message should indicate the line number where the issue exists. See the debug console error message below does not give me an indication where the problem is. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19569706/9e057a44-96ab-11e6-80c3-6ba0e21e314e.png)

To fix this today, I simply need to add the `key` property. 

``` json
{
  "mac": "cmd+shift+l",
  "win": "ctrl+shift+l",
  "linux": "ctrl+shift+l",
  "key": "ctrl+shift+l",
  "command": "editor.action.insertCursorAtEndOfEachLineSelected",
  "when": "editorTextFocus"
}
```

As an aside, I created https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14112 to address the necessity of the `"key"` property.

data.title: Visual Studio Code is not Light Enough

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Visual Studio Community Edition is a free editor and I work with it on desktop.

So the purpose of VS Code should be to open code files in server enviroments, or PC's without VS Installed.
It should be like notepad++ does but with full syntax support.

It is great but it still takes 10 seconds to start up on a fast PC. I think you should load less necessary features on demand.

Also I need to be able to start and debug a sln or csprj file. It just displays me inner xml, no run button.
So I get no useful feature of IDE. All I have is a very slow loading text editor with syntax highlight support

Of course it has much more features but please focus on the most basic use cases

data.title: editor.formatOnType does not respect editor.insertSpaces setting
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.6.1
- OS Version:
  OSX (10.11.6)
### Searchable description

VS Code keeps changing some lines to have spaces instead of tabs in the leading whitespace.
### Steps to Reproduce:

Use these settings:
    "editor.tabSize": 4,
    "editor.insertSpaces": false,
    "editor.detectIndentation": false,
    "editor.formatOnType": true,

Type some code that triggers formatOnType to activate a format change.
### Expected behaviour:

Line is formatted using tabs for leading whitespace, because of the insertSpaces setting.
### Actual behaviour:

Line is formatted with spaces instead of tabs for the leading whitespace.

data.title: editor shows garbage from time to time
data.body:
Related to mac os, view zone, and scroll with momentum.

The steps are:
- click somewhere on a symbol at the top of the file
- move mouse somewhere to a line at the bottom of the file
- jiggle the mouse wheel slightly
- press Shift+F12

> This creates a view zone that pushes the div that was scrolled on outside the viewport, but due to it being the last scrolled dom node, it stays around until scrolling in the opposite direction.

data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - fold levels 6-9
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is folding on levels 6 through 9. Today we only fold until level 5. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**

| Windows / Linux | Mac | Fold Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | 6 |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | 7 |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | 8 |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | 9 |

data.title: Horizontal Layout Workspace Setting
data.body:
When you have a `workspace` setting for laying out the editors e.g. 
`"workbench.editor.sideBySideLayout": "horizontal"`

The toggle options (which are user settings) do nothing e.g. clicking on:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/19566721/a28f8222-96eb-11e6-99ae-ed5ec74897eb.png)

It could be worth testing to see if a workspace setting exists.  If it does then tell the user that the toggle will not override this setting.  As a result it will do nothing.

The same is true for this menu option - it does nothing as the workspace setting overrides it:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/19566819/e9f16252-96eb-11e6-8a62-4218ede5f6e6.png)

In this case I'm already in horizontal layout so we probably need an additional check to validate the workspace setting mode before rendering the item.

data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - close HTML tag
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is close HTML tag. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**
Windows / Linux: <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd>
Mac: <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd>

![close_html_tag](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19566803/6f8e46f6-96a0-11e6-923e-796c4600c987.gif)

Today an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Compulim.compulim-vscode-closetag) exists that provides this feature. I believe we should bring this into the product.

data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - wrap HTML tag
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is wrap HTML tag. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**
Windows / Linux: <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd>
Mac: <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd>

![wrap_html_tag](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19566700/1e0b12a0-96a0-11e6-860d-6687a56d0061.gif)

An [extension exists](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Compulim.compulim-vscode-closetag) to provide functionality that is close to but not quite on par. I think we should bring this into the core product.

data.title: Fold the default settings by default
data.body:
Fold the default settings by default
- [x] Fold the Default settings by default
- [x] Retain the state of Default settings while switching editors
- [x] Retain the state of Default settings when closed and opened
- [x] Retain the state for Default Keyboard shortcuts while switching editors
- [x] Retain the state of Default Keyboard shortcuts when closed and opened
